text: <@U0260V1BX>: yum!
New bike traffic counters! I have high hopes for the data that will come of this <http://bikeportland.org/2015/01/13/50-device-change-bike-planning-forever-130891>

attachments.title: This $50 device could change bike planning forever - BikePortland.org
attachments.fallback: BikePortland.org: This $50 device could change bike planning forever - BikePortland.org

text: wow
looks very familiar
that's cool
<http://seattletimes.com/ABPub/2012/10/11/2019409068.jpg>
the article's not about those big permanent counters tho
but little permanent counters!
It would be relatively cheap to hook those up to some led display, right?
are the ones in the article permanent even? i got the idea they could be moved around and reused
I suppose so. but I got the idea that they'd be at least semi-permanently installed, so that differences like construction and long-term weather effects could be measured
true

Adoption is where this falls apart.  You have to have the app on your phone.  Correct me if I'm wrong, but if I need an app and I need it to be on, couldn't that alone just capture data about when I'm on my bike?
you don't need the app for the counter to count you tho
I know these are sensors/receivers
Ahh, I need to re-read this then.
Truthfully, the "in" would be to sell people affordable tech that protects their bike in the case of theft (and package this utility within it).
I want to know where my bike is once it's ripped off ("Find my iPhone"-style) more than I care about urban planning.  But, then again, I'm a selfish yuppie.
"Instead, it detects every passer-by — with or without a smartphone — and keeps a count in its simple, tiny onboard computer. " - Cool

"...when someone who’s installed a special smartphone app passes within 20 or 30 feet of his device. Every time that happens, the device uses a low-energy Bluetooth signal to pass the information to that person’s smartphone, which then uses its own Internet connection to pass the stockpiled bike counts anonymously into the cloud." - Crafty.  Some might say "tricky."  Then again, I might just be being cynical.  I care enough to download the app and they tell me the whole reason for doing so is to help the city gather better data, I'm probably glad to help.
Can't mess with $50.  That's incredible.

It's similar to how those time estimates work on the highway ("15 min to tunnel" etc). A Bluetooth sensor in the gridlock will find a particular MAC address among the drivers, then another sensor at the tunnel entrance will see the same one 15 minutes later.
but in that case the two sensors are wired to communicate with each other.

Yeah.  I remember realizing how that worked had to be info from all the phones in all the cars around me on the road.  If it's useful, we'll let ourselves be tracked.  This falls into that category, especially given how passionate people are about (or against) urban cycling.
Thanks for sharing.  Back to work.

<http://vimeo.com/116582567> <http://www.thisiscolossal.com/2015/01/fascinating-3d-printed-fibonacci-zoetrope-sculptures/>

attachments.title: Fibonacci Zoetrope Sculptures
attachments.text:
These are 3-D printed sculptures designed to animate when spun under a strobe light. The placement of the appendages is determined by the same method nature uses in pinecones and sunflowers.  The rotation speed is synchronized to the strobe so that one flash occurs every time the sculpture turns 137.5º—the golden angle. If you count the number of spirals on any of these sculptures you will find that they are always Fibonacci numbers. 

For this video, rather than using a strobe, the camera was set to a very short shutter speed (1/4000 sec) in order to freeze the spinning sculpture.

John Edmark is an inventor/designer/artist. He teaches design at Stanford University.

Visit John's website here: <http://web.stanford.edu/~edmark/>
and Vimeo site: <https://vimeo.com/johnedmark/videos>

Learn how he made these sculptures here: <http://www.instructables.com/id/Blooming-Zoetrope-Sculptures/>

And more about the Pier 9 Artist in Residence program here: <http://www.autodesk.com/air>
